projectPurpose: To improve the performance and efficiency of Apache Spark workloads by providing a high-performance, native execution engine plugin built on Apache DataFusion and Apache Arrow.
mainFeatures: Accelerates Apache Spark query execution using a native runtime
Built on Apache DataFusion and Apache Arrow
Seamless integration with Spark, no code changes required
Aims for feature parity with Spark operators and expressions
Automatic fallback to Spark for unsupported features
Supports native Parquet read and write
UDF framework for native migration

alternatives.name: Velox
mainFeatures: Composable and extensible C++ execution engine library
Reusable data processing components
Integrates with various data systems (e.g., Presto, Spark via Gluten)
Supports columnar memory layout and vectorized execution
Used by major tech companies

alternatives.name: Gluten
mainFeatures: Middle layer to offload Spark SQL to native engines
Bridge between Spark JVM and native execution engines (like Velox)
Uses Apache Arrow and Substrait
Enables leveraging vectorized libraries and hardware accelerators in Spark

alternatives.name: Blaze
mainFeatures: Spark accelerator using native vectorized execution
Leverages Apache DataFusion as core execution engine
Compatible with Spark programming interface
Maps Spark physical plan to DataFusion execution plan
Supports different Spark versions

alternatives.name: NVIDIA RAPIDS Accelerator for Apache Spark
mainFeatures: Accelerates Spark applications using GPUs
Focuses on Spark SQL and DataFrame operations
Integrates with RAPIDS libraries
Requires no code changes to Spark applications

alternatives.name: Databricks Photon
mainFeatures: Vectorized native query engine
Written in C++
Designed for fast data processing on data lakes
Integrated within the Databricks Lakehouse Platform

marketPositioning: Apache DataFusion Comet is positioned as a high-performance open-source accelerator for Apache Spark, unique in its foundation on the Rust-based DataFusion query engine and the Apache Arrow columnar format. It aims to provide a seamless, drop-in replacement for parts of Spark's execution layer, offering performance benefits through native, vectorized execution without requiring users to alter their existing Spark code. This distinguishes it from proprietary solutions like Databricks Photon and offers an alternative technical approach to other native acceleration efforts like those based on C++ engines such as Velox (often integrated via Gluten) or GPU-focused solutions like NVIDIA RAPIDS. Its commitment to feature parity and automatic fallback makes it an accessible option for Spark users seeking performance improvements within the Apache open-source ecosystem.
